meanings.def: having a shape like a circle or a ball
examples: a round plate
These glasses suit people with round faces.
The fruit are small and round.
Rugby isn't played with a round ball.
the discovery that the world is round
The child was watching it all with big round eyes (= showing interest).
a T-shirt with a round neck
a coin with a round hole in the centre
The tower was perfectly round.
They sat at a large round table.

meanings.def: having a curved shape
examples: the round green hills of Donegal
Put both the surname and publication date in round brackets.
She had a small mouth and round pink cheeks.
Choose shoes with a flat sole and round toes.

meanings.def: a round figure or amount is one that is given as a whole number, usually one ending in 0
examples: Make it a round figure—say forty dollars.
Two thousand is a nice round number—put that down.
Well, in round figures (= not giving the exact figures) we've spent twenty thousand so far.
The total was a round $30 million in Australian dollars.

meanings.def: moving in a circle
examples: Everybody joins hands and dances round.
How do you make the wheels go round?
The children were spinning round and round.
(figurative) The thought kept going round and round in her head.
Love makes the world go round.

meanings.def: measuring or marking the edge or outside of something
examples: a young tree measuring only 18 inches round
They've built a high fence all round to keep intruders out.

meanings.def: on all sides of somebody/something
examples: A large crowd had gathered round to watch.

meanings.def: at various places in an area
examples: People stood round waiting for something to happen.

meanings.def: in a circle or curve to face another way or the opposite way
examples: He turned the car round and drove back again.
She looked round at the sound of his voice.
Harvey spun round to face him.

meanings.def: to the other side of something
examples: We walked round to the back of the house.
The road's blocked—you'll have to drive the long way round.

meanings.def: from one place, person, etc. to another
examples: They've moved all the furniture round.
He went round interviewing people about local traditions.
Pass the biscuits round.
Have we enough cups to go round?
Rumours are going round that she's pregnant again.

meanings.def: to or at a particular place, especially where somebody lives
examples: I'll be round in an hour.
We've invited the Frasers round this evening.
Edward loved her cooking and regularly came round to supper.
The earth goes round/​around the sun.
They live round/​around the corner.
We travelled round/​around India.
She turned round/​around when I came in.
The kids were running around/​round/​about outside.
I’ve been waiting around/​round/​about to see her all day.
We left around/​about 8 o’clock.

meanings.def: on the next, first, etc. occasion that the same thing happens
examples: He repeated none of the errors he'd made first time round.
This time round it was not so easy.

meanings.def: approximately
examples: We're leaving round about ten.
A new roof will cost round about £3 000.

meanings.def: in the area near a place
examples: in Oxford and the villages round about

idioms.idiom: (the) next, first, second, etc. time round
idioms.def: on the next, first, etc. occasion that the same thing happens
examples: He repeated none of the errors he'd made first time round.
This time round it was not so easy.
We're leaving round about ten.
A new roof will cost round about £3 000.
in Oxford and the villages round about

meanings.def: in a circle
examples: the first woman to sail round the world
The earth moves round the sun.

meanings.def: on, to or from the other side of something
examples: Our house is round the next bend.
There she is, coming round the corner.
(figurative) There must be a way round (= a way of solving) the problem.

meanings.def: on all sides of somebody/something; surrounding somebody/something
examples: She put her arms round him.
He had a scarf round his neck.
They were all sitting round the table.

meanings.def: in or to many parts of something
examples: She looked all round the room.

meanings.def: to fit in with particular people, ideas, etc.
examples: He has to organize his life round the kids.
The earth goes round/​around the sun.
They live round/​around the corner.
We travelled round/​around India.
She turned round/​around when I came in.
The kids were running around/​round/​about outside.
I’ve been waiting around/​round/​about to see her all day.
We left around/​about 8 o’clock.

meanings.def: a difficult problem or responsibility that it seems impossible to solve or get rid of
examples: My debts are a millstone around my neck.
Unemployment was an economic millstone around the country’s neck.

meanings.def: near where you are now or where you live
examples: There are no decent schools round here.

idioms.def: a difficult problem or responsibility that it seems impossible to solve or get rid of
examples: My debts are a millstone around my neck.
Unemployment was an economic millstone around the country’s neck.

idioms.def: near where you are now or where you live
examples: There are no decent schools round here.

meanings.def: a stage in a competition or sports event
examples: the qualifying rounds of the National Championships
Anderson was knocked out of the tournament in the third round.
He beat Fischer in the opening round.
She made it through to the final round.
They were drawn to face Wigan in the preliminary round.
Norwich City are through to the third round of the FA Cup.
Italy qualified for the second round of the tournament by beating Germany.
He has never made the fourth round of the tournament.

meanings.def: a stage in a boxing or wrestling match
examples: The fight only lasted five rounds.
Ali won the next round convincingly.

meanings.def: a complete game of golf; a complete way around the course in some other sports, such as showjumping
examples: We played a round of golf.
I finished the practice round and went in to have lunch.
the first horse to jump a clear round

meanings.def: a set of events which form part of a longer process
examples: the next round of peace talks
a new round of pay bargaining
the final round of voting in the election
This latest round of redundancies follows the loss of 250 jobs in January.
There were two important rounds of negotiations.
He won the second round of the elections.

meanings.def: a regular series of activities
examples: the daily round of school life
Her life is one long round of parties and fun.

meanings.def: a regular route that somebody takes when delivering or collecting something; a regular series of visits that somebody makes
examples: on your round Dr Green was on her daily ward rounds.
(British English) a postman on his delivery round
Four soldiers patrolled the area and an officer made his rounds at frequent intervals.
The milkman does his round very early.

meanings.def: a number of drinks bought by one person for all the others in a group
examples: a round of drinks
It's my round (= it is my turn to pay for the next set of drinks).
I bought the last round.
We just had time for one more round of drinks.

meanings.def: a whole slice of bread; sandwiches made from two whole slices of bread
examples: Who's for another round of toast?
two rounds of beef sandwiches

meanings.def: a round object or piece of something
examples: Cut the pastry into rounds.

meanings.def: a short period during which people show their approval of somebody/something by clapping
examples: There was a great round of applause when the dance ended.

meanings.def: a single shot from a gun; a bullet for one shot
examples: They fired several rounds at the crowd.
We only have three rounds of ammunition left.

meanings.def: a song for two or more voices in which each sings the same tune but starts at a different time
if news or a joke does the rounds, it is passed on quickly from one person to another
to go around from place to place, especially when looking for work or support for a political campaign, etc.
examples: He’s doing the rounds of insurance firms.
The Vice-President made the rounds of television talk shows.

meanings.def: made so that it can be seen from all sides
examples: an opportunity to see Canova’s work in the round

meanings.def: with the people watching all around a central stage

idioms.def: if news or a joke does the rounds, it is passed on quickly from one person to another
examples: He’s doing the rounds of insurance firms.
The Vice-President made the rounds of television talk shows.

idioms.def: made so that it can be seen from all sides
examples: an opportunity to see Canova’s work in the round

meanings.def: to go around a corner of a building, a bend in the road, etc.
examples: The boat rounded the tip of the island.
We rounded the bend at high speed.

meanings.def: to make something into a round shape; to form into a round shape
examples: She rounded her lips and whistled.
His eyes rounded with horror.

meanings.def: to increase or decrease a number to the next highest or lowest whole number
